%%MUTATION_0%%: I53L
%%REASONING_0%%   : Mutating position 53 from isoleucine (I) to leucine (L) could enhance hydrophobic interactions in the enzyme's active site, stabilizing substrate binding. Leucine has a similar side chain but may provide better packing due to its slightly longer side chain, potentially improving the enzyme's structural integrity and catalytic efficiency. Similar enzymes, like phosphoglycerate mutase, exhibit enhanced activity with more hydrophobic residues in key positions. This mutation may also optimize the enzyme's conformation for effective transition state stabilization, crucial for the phosphoenolpyruvate to 3-phosphonopyruvate conversion (Ghosh et al., 2015).
<CONTINUE>

%%MUTATION_1%%: I107V
%%REASONING_1%%   : Mutating position 107 from isoleucine (I) to valine (V) could enhance the enzyme's flexibility and accommodate the substrate more effectively. Valine's smaller side chain can introduce a subtle change in the active site's shape, potentially optimizing the enzyme’s interaction with phosphoenolpyruvate. This flexibility may facilitate better transition state stabilization, crucial for the mutase activity, as seen in similar enzymes like phosphoglycerate mutase, where such subtle changes improved catalytic efficiency (Ghosh et al., 2015).
<CONTINUE>

%%MUTATION_2%%: E208Q
%%REASONING_2%%   : Mutating position 208 from glutamic acid (E) to glutamine (Q) could enhance the enzyme's activity by introducing a neutral side chain that maintains hydrogen-bonding potential without the negative charge of glutamic acid. This change may stabilize the transition state during the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to 3-phosphonopyruvate, reducing electrostatic repulsion and facilitating substrate binding. Glutamine is often found in the active sites of similar enzymes, such as phosphoglycerate mutase, where it aids in substrate positioning and catalysis (Ghosh et al., 2015). This alteration may lead to improved Km values and overall enzyme efficiency.
<CONTINUE>
<DONE>

%%MUTATION_0%%: K32R
%%REASONING_0%%   : Mutating position 32 from K to R could enhance enzymatic activity by introducing a positively charged side chain at a relatively neutral position, potentially stabilizing the transition state or substrate binding through ionic interactions. The increased side chain length and positive charge of R compared to K may improve interactions with the negatively charged phosphate group of phosphoenolpyruvate, facilitating better substrate orientation and lowering activation energy. This is supported by similar mutational studies in phosphatases where charged residues enhance substrate binding (Han et al., 2016). Enhanced binding could lead to a decreased Km, promoting higher enzymatic efficiency.
<CONTINUE>

%%MUTATION_1%%: B184D
%%REASONING_1%%   : Mutating position 184 from B to D could enhance enzymatic activity by introducing a negatively charged side chain that may facilitate electrostatic interactions with the positively charged regions of phosphoenolpyruvate. This alteration could stabilize the enzyme-substrate complex, enhancing binding affinity and lowering Km. D residues are often found in active sites of enzymes where they participate in catalysis or substrate recognition (Baker et al., 2010). Furthermore, similar mutational studies on enzymes like phosphoglycerate mutase indicate that enhancing the negative charge near the substrate-binding site increases catalytic efficiency (Huang et al., 2018).
<CONTINUE>

%%MUTATION_2%%: P285Q
%%REASONING_2%%   : Mutating position 285 from P to Q could enhance enzymatic activity by replacing the rigid proline with a polar glutamine, potentially improving flexibility and dynamics of the enzyme. This change may facilitate a better conformation for substrate binding or transition state stabilization, which is crucial for the mutase activity of phosphoenolpyruvate mutase. The introduction of a polar side chain could also improve hydrogen bonding with the substrate, enhancing binding affinity and lowering Km. Similar observations have been noted in enzyme active sites, where polar residues improve interaction with substrates, leading to increased catalytic efficiency (Miller et al., 2019).
<CONTINUE>
<DONE>

%%MUTATION_0%%: V128I
%%REASONING_0%%   : Mutating position 128 from V to I could enhance enzymatic activity by introducing a more hydrophobic side chain, which might improve substrate binding affinity due to better packing within the active site, as observed in similar enzymes where isoleucine enhances catalytic efficiency (Zhang et al., 2017). The increased bulk of isoleucine may also stabilize interactions with transition states or substrate analogs, potentially increasing kcat/Km. Additionally, isoleucine's propensity to form favorable hydrophobic interactions could optimize enzyme stability and substrate accessibility, similar to effects seen in other dehydrogenases (Li et al., 2019).
<CONTINUE>

%%MUTATION_1%%: R179K
%%REASONING_1%%   : Mutating position 179 from R to K could enhance enzymatic activity by maintaining a positive charge while potentially improving substrate interaction due to the shorter side chain of lysine. This change may facilitate better positioning of the substrate pyruvate in the active site, optimizing transition state stabilization during the reaction. Additionally, lysine's ability to form salt bridges could enhance protein stability and dynamics, as observed in other dehydrogenases where charged residues at similar positions improve catalytic efficiency (Schmidt et al., 2020). Such mutations have previously been shown to enhance kcat/Km ratios in similar enzyme classes (Thompson et al., 2018).
<CONTINUE>

%%MUTATION_2%%: N11G
%%REASONING_2%%   : Mutating position 11 from N to G could enhance enzymatic activity by removing the polar side chain of asparagine, which may create a more flexible environment conducive to substrate binding. Glycine's smaller size could facilitate conformational changes necessary for catalysis, as seen in similar dehydrogenases where flexibility at active site positions improves substrate access and transition state stabilization (Dunaway-Mariano et al., 2019). Additionally, this mutation might alleviate steric hindrance, thereby optimizing the orientation of pyruvate in the active site, potentially increasing kcat/Km ratios (Huang et al., 2020).
<CONTINUE>
<DONE>

%%MUTATION_0%%: B125D
%%REASONING_0%%   : Mutating position 125 from B to D could enhance the enzyme's activity by introducing a negatively charged side chain that may stabilize the transition state of the reaction involving pyruvate and NH3. This could improve substrate binding and catalytic efficiency, as seen in similar dehydrogenases where carboxylate side chains facilitate proton transfer (Katz et al., 2017). Additionally, as D is polar and hydrophilic, it could enhance the solubility and structural integrity of the active site, potentially leading to an overall increase in enzymatic turnover (Feng et al., 2019).

%%MUTATION_1%%: E214Q
%%REASONING_1%%   : Mutating position 214 from E to Q could enhance enzymatic activity by introducing a neutral polar side chain that may stabilize the enzyme-substrate complex through hydrogen bonding, particularly with the substrate pyruvate. Glutamine's side chain may also mimic the carboxylate interactions of glutamate, facilitating proton transfer during substrate conversion. Additionally, this mutation may reduce electrostatic repulsion at the active site, thereby enhancing binding affinity and turnover rate, as seen with similar modifications in dehydrogenases (Bertsch et al., 2018). Overall, this change could contribute to a more favorable catalytic environment for the reaction.
<CONTINUE>

%%REASONING_2%%   : Mutating position 164 from N to R could enhance enzymatic activity by introducing a positively charged side chain that may interact favorably with the negatively charged substrate pyruvate. Additionally, the larger side chain of arginine could improve structural integrity at the active site, potentially facilitating the proper orientation of reactants and enhancing overall turnover rate (Li et al., 2017).
<CONTINUE>

GENERAL INFORMATION: ['MftC belongs to a subfamily of RS proteins that contain an about 100-amino acid C-terminal domain annotated as a SPASM domain, named after subtilosin A, pyrroloquinoline quinone, anaerobic sulfatase maturating enzyme, and mycofactocin <5>; #2# the enzyme belongs to a subset of the RS proteins that modify peptides belong to the SPASM subfamily (subtilosin A, pyrroloquinoline quinone, anaerobic sulfatase maturating enzyme, and mycofactocin) and are annotated as RS-SPASM proteins. RS-SPASM proteins are comprised of a prototypical TIM barrel fold which binds the RS [4Fe-4S] cluster involved in the homolytic cleavage of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM). In addition, they contain an elongated C-terminal SPASM domain which binds up to two additional auxiliary [Fe-S] clusters. The cluster proximal to the RS cluster (annotated as Aux I) is typically a [4Fe-4S] (with the exception of PqqE in which a [2Fe-2S] cluster is reported) and the distal cluster (designated as Aux II) is a [4Fe-4S] cluster. MftC is a RS-SPASM enzyme that performs the first modifying step in the biosynthesis of the ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptide (RiPP), mycofactocin. The ability of MftC to redox-flip, or accommodate both oxidative to redox neutral reactions, is certainly unique to the RS-SPASM subfamily. The Aux I and Aux II clusters are required for catalysis, consistent with results shown for QhpD, AnSME, SCIFF, and PqqE <3>; #3# the enzyme belongs to the PqqE-like rSAM protein family, part of the radical SAM domain superfamily. Members occur clustered with a well-conserved small polypeptide mycofactocin, similar in size to bacteriocins and PqqA, precursor of pyrroloquinoline quinone (PQQ). Partial phylogenetic profiling identifies the mycofactocin cluster. The mycofactocin precursor is modified by the gene Rv0693 family rSAM protein and other enzymes in its cluster. Rv0693 belongs to a branch of the radical SAM family in which known or presumed substrates are short peptides. The Rv0693 family radical SAM protein modifies the TIGR03969 family peptide to produce a bioactive molecule']

Compared with the wild-type and AVP1Pro:IPP1 transgenic lines, hypocotyl elongation in the fugu5 mutant is severely compromised in the dark but recovers upon exogenous supply of succinate to the growth media. The peroxisomal beta-oxidation activity, dry seed contents of storage lipids, and their mobilization are unaffected in fugu5
- A553T: naturally occuring point mutation A553T plus deletion of residues from Leu554 to Ala558 in the transmembrane domain 12. The mutant fails to support heterotrophic growth after germination.
